case_vignette: A 75-year-old male presents with a few day history of blisters developing on his arms and legs. He denies any exposures to poison ivy, any recent travel, and any recent medication changes. Physical examination demonstrates thin urticarial pink plaques on the abdomen and multiple tense bullae without significant underlying erythema scattered on the arms and legs.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have blisters developing on my arms and legs and I also have thin pink patches on my abdomen.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for a few days.
Have you recently started any new medications or been exposed to any new substances?
No, I haven't had any recent medication changes or exposures to new substances like poison ivy.
Do the blisters itch, burn, or cause any pain?
The description didn't specify those sensations, so I can't provide details on itching, burning, or pain.
Do you have any known allergies or a family history of skin diseases?
I haven't mentioned any known allergies or a family history of skin diseases.
Have you experienced anything similar in the past, or is this the first occurrence?
This is the first occurrence; I haven't experienced anything similar in the past.
Final Diagnosis: Pityriasis Rosea.
